thread.title: VASJ fires on all cylinders for 5th straight district title, 75-45 vs. Warrensville Heights
thread.title_full: VASJ fires on all cylinders for 5th straight district title, 75-45 vs. Warrensville Heights

author: Matt Goul, cleveland.com
title: VASJ fires on all cylinders for 5th straight district title, 75-45 vs. Warrensville Heights
text:
GARFIELD HEIGHTS, Ohio – The public address announcer caught himself Friday night as he introduced Villa Angela-St. Joseph as the Division III state boys basketball champion. 
There are still two weeks left in the postseason for that to even happen. 
Nick Labelle quickly corrected himself to anoint VASJ the Division III district champions following a 75-45 blowout of Warrensville Heights . 
Consider Tigers coach Brian Swift a believer that it might just be a matter of time until Labelle is made a prophet. 
“They’re going to be tough to beat,” he said. “We all know, coming out of Garfield and Northeast Ohio, it’s a tough, tough district. I think they have a great shot.” 
No one on Swift’s seventh-seeded Tigers (11-15) had experienced district championship. VASJ (19-6) entered its seventh in a row and left with a fifth straight crown. The Vikings, who are in pursuit of their fifth straight OHSAA state championship game appearance, will next play in the Division III regional semifinals Wednesday at Canton Fieldhouse. They will face Warren District champion Garrettsville Garfield, which upset Leavittsburg LaBrae, 58-56. They will meet at 8 p.m., following the first regional semifinal between West Salem Northwestern and Louisville St. Thomas Aquinas. 
Aquinas is a North Coast League rival of VASJ and part of a stiff schedule that Jerry Higgins said he thinks separated the Vikings. 
“We love the big-game stage,” the junior point guard said. “We played such a tough schedule and showed the intensity from everyone.” 
Higgins scored a game-high 21 points and dished out six assists. He found 6-8 sophomore Alonzo Gaffney on four of those assists, which led to Gaffney’s 20-point, nine-rebound effort. Alonzo Gaffney w/13 points, but he's minus-1 on a piece of gum. pic.twitter.com/HrbsA8oVaC — Matt Goul (@mgoul) March 11, 2017 
Gaffney pushed VASJ ahead early with jump shots from the baseline and perimeter. He had eight in the first quarter, mostly in the first three minutes when Swift said he thought the game got away. 
If it wasn’t Gaffney’s baskets, Will Butler ’s high-arcing 3s did it. The senior guard had two of them in the first quarter, then closed the second with another just before the buzzer. VASJ led 35-14. 
Warrensville never led. Senior guard Joseph Vallery led the Tigers with 15 points and Sha'Mar Latham added 12 in their final game. Will Butler has three 3s at the half, including this rainbow to close the second qtr. pic.twitter.com/uw0oy29fNA — Matt Goul (@mgoul) March 11, 2017 
“We wanted to come out and punch them in the mouth,” said Butler, who finished with 16 points. 
A hulking 6-1 guard, Butler is characterized by coach Babe Kwasniak as the team’s “MVP.” Kwasniak added Butler usually has just “one speed,” but he played with a greater sense of urgency. 
Butler credited assistant coach Rich Newlon for that. Newlon delivered a passionate pregame speech in VASJ’s chapel before departing to Garfield Heights. 
“It really pumped us out and got us ready from the beginning,” Butler said. 
Kwasniak added, “It was one of the best things I’ve been a part of. It was spectacular.” 
VASJ is 5-of-5 in district title games with Newlon on staff. Kwasniak brings in a guest speaker before each game and selected Newlon for this one. 
Newlon instructed each player to grab hands. For about 20 minutes, he told the players of his expectations from each of them. Much of it dealt with inspiring each other, Higgins said. 
They saw Warrensville enter this gym a few days earlier and score the first 17 points to beat Gilmour in the semifinals. Higgins, Butler and Co. tried to do the same.
